column1: Should pale death with treble dread make the ocean caves our bed, God who hear'st the surges roll, deign to save the suppliant soul.
column3: Bad luck to leave a toast unfinished, lad.
column5: Didn’t picture you was a readin’ man.
column6: Then y’do as I say. That’s in yer book, too.
column7: Aye. The cistern needs a-lookin’ to. One of yer duties, lad. Or didn’t y’read yerself about it? Polishin’, swabbin’. Swabbin’ and polishin’. You’ll clean the brass and the clockwork, and you can tidy the quarters after. There’s well- more to be mended outside.
column10: When the fog clears, you’ll work through the dog watch--
column11: It’s the mid watch that’s to dread, lad: night to morning. My watch.
column12: Some new junior man I’m fixed with-- Y’act like y’never been to sea a’fore.
column14: I’m meanin’ y’ain’t fit fer the wearin’ of it. See to yer duties. The light’s mine.
column17: Tend to ‘em after the cistern. And the lamp, she needs oil.
column20: Use this next time. Save you a helluva lotta trouble.
column22: Then bring that drum back down the ladderwell where y’found it. ‘Less yer fixin’ to burn the whole light down.
column23: Then see to the rest of yer duties. Yer behindhand already.
column24: Yer too slow. You a dullard?
column26: Should pale death with treble dread make the ocean caves our bed, God who hear'st the surges roll, deign to save the suppliant soul.
column28: Ah, find some chirk in ye, lad. Now is the time for gab and chatter. Y’best be enjoying it. Come a fortnight and the brace of us’ll be wantin’ to be ever silent as the tomb. Even to clap eyes on each other... It’ll make y’hotter than hell!
column30: Y’ain’t. Y’ain’t. Aye, the Chicopee, a fine-un, she were. Clean-built and trig-lookin’! None more fleet in ‘64 than she... We were on the breaks -- a mutiny it were. And why, ask ye? Why? What’s the terrible part of the sailor’s life ask ye, lad? T’ain’t Cap’n, workin’ ‘em double-tide. Nay, no.
column31: ‘Tis when the workin’ stops when yer twixt wind and water. Doldrums. Doldrums. Eviler than the Devil. Boredom makes men to villains... And the water goes quick, lad... vanished. And what’s the answer? What be the cure? The only med’cine is drink. Drink, lad! Keeps them sailors happy, keeps ‘em agreeable, keeps ’em calm, keeps em–-
column32: Curse me if there ain’t an old tar spirit somewheres in ye, lad.
column35: Aye, went mad, he did. First a strangeness. A quietude. Then wild fancies struck him. Ravin’ ‘bout sirens, merfolk, bad omens and the like. In the end, no more sense left in him than a hen’s tooth. He believed there were some enchantment in the light.
column36: He notioned St. Elmo did cast his very fire into it. Salvation, said he.
column37: Best y’leave ‘em be. Bad luck to kill a sea bird.
column38: Bad luck to kill a sea bird.
column39: Pay me no mind, lad. None. Fix us up some coffee. Long night ahead. Drop o’coffee‘ll do us good.
column40: You’ve been neglecting yer duties, lad!
column49: And I say y’did nothin’ o’the sort.
column51: Now that’s a good lad. That’s what
column52: Oh what be the bane of a lightkeeper's life? What cause him to worry, to struggle and strife, What make him use cuss words, and beat at his wife? ‘Tis Brasswork.
column53: What make him look ghastly, consumptive and thin? What rob him of health, of his vigor and vim? And cause him despair and drives him to sin.' ‘Tis Brasswork.
column54: The oil containers I polish until, My poor back is broken, aching; and still...
column56: Whitewash must be even, lad. Bright! Shinin’!
column57: Like a silver whorehouse token. Give ‘em sailors a proper daymark.
column58: They will after! And'll be glad to see it! Keep your temper now, lad. ‘Tis fine work. Yer makin’ high marks in me logbook. Them’s gospel!
column59: I'll drop y’down a few feet.
column66: Listen to ye, giving orders, lad.
column67: Alright, alright... suits me just as fine, Ephraim Winslow. So, what brung such a one as you to this damnèd rock?
column70: Winslow -– What brings you to this rock, Ephraim Winslow? What were yer work afore?
column73: True what they say? “Forest far as the eye can see.”
column74: Had enough of trees, that it, then?
column75: Can’t say I blame ye. I hearn tell about that life. Hard goin’. Workin’ one man harder than two hosses, they say. No thankee. The sea, she’s the only situation wantin’ fer me.
column76: Miss it? I ain’t never know’d anything but it.
column78: Ain’t nothing what can touch it.
column79: But can’t be draggin’ me old stump about...  Nay... not worth the trouble... now I’m a wickie and a wickie I is. I’m damn-well wedded to this here light, and she’s been a finer, truer, quieter wife than any a live- blooded woman.
column80: Thirteen Christmases at sea... little ‘uns at home. She never forgave it.
column82: Since we’re getting too friendly, Ephraim Winslow, tell me, what’s a timber man want with being a wickie? Not enough quiet for ye up north? Sawdust itching yer nethers? Foreman found ye too high-tempered for carrying an axe?
column87: In ‘em’s the souls o’ sailors what met their maker.
column89: Russian Tar once told me: yer cigarette cinder goes out, there be someone somewhere’s a-thinkin’ bad thoughts of ye.
column94: Don’t be so darn foolish. It’s the calm afore the storm, Winslow. She were a gentle westerly wind yer cursin’. Only feels roughly ‘cause you don’t know nothin’ bout nothin’ and there ain’t no trees on this here rock like your Hudson Bay bush. Nor’Easterly wind’ll come soon a-blowin’ like Gabriel’s horn. Best board up them signal house winders.
column95: ‘Twill keep steady afore the tender comes in the morn, I ‘spect... but there’s dirty weather knockin’ about.
column96: Somethin’ stirring in ye? Yer gettin’ off this island tomorry Winslow, don’t start grudgen me now.
column99: Pull, pull, me good lad. Pull, Winslow!
column100: Look at ‘em! Better than fin fishin’!
column101: ‘Tis no crime to take a snort now.
column102: And bein’ our last afore relief, I never know’d an inspector what wouldn’t turn a blind eye, and I won’t take “no” for an answer.
column104: When we're arrived on Bedford docks Them bloomers all comin’round in flocks Them pretty girls, we hear 'em say "Here comes Jack with his nine- month pay"
column105: ...and a pretty lass, she were, takin’ off her bonnet... but as I says, I’d broke me leg, and banged myself all up. It was to a nuns' hospital... All of them nuns were Catholics, I tell ye...
column106: Aye, but I never went to Salem since without hoping that I should see her, for beddin’ down wer’nt the same since. I don't know, but if I was a-goin’ to begin me life over again... well, womenfolk are apt to be dreadful ashamed of it, anyhow.
column107: Well, I’ll say it... I might even miss ye, Ephraim Winslow, yer fastly a true blue wickie in the making, you is. Thought one night you was bound to split me skull in twain, but yer a good-un. Why you’ll be workin’ the lamp in no time –
column109: I’m the keeper of this station, lad.
column110: My log is the only book on this rock--
column111: I’m the keeper of the light, lad, I never let no man touch her--
column117: Y’smell o’ shit. Best swab this mess afore the tender comes.
column118: Y’do as yer told, lad! The quarters are dire.
column121: ‘Tis frost and snow and winter storm.  Go down ye blood red roses, go down!  And there’s many a ship lost round Cape Horn.  Go down ye blood red roses, go down!  Oh, ye pinks and posies... EIGHT... Go down!
column122: Well, the captain he's o’er come with fear. Go down –-
column123: The damp‘s got to the foodstuffs. The salt cod is out.
column132: It’s been weeks ago since we missed her, Winslow. And I’ve been askin’ ye to ration fer weeks now, too, and you’ve kept barking at me like a mad dog, sayin’ you can “take the dory out”--
column133: Don’t be losing yer head now.
column134: No, it ain’t. And I ain’t wantin’ to be stranded here with some damned lunatic.
column136: If we can wait out this storm.
column137: In ‘75 ‘Ol Striker were marooned here for seven long months, he was. The storm died on the mainland but here, waters were too rageful neither to launch nor land.
column138: Look at ye. Pretendin’. But ye well- know yer lot.
column139: ... their gums grew swollen, the color of bone, then to rot. Tarry blood oozed, teeth droppin’ to deck with none to hold on to.
column147: Who, Winslow? The eaves be fallin’--
column149: Raggin’? Who’s raggin’? What island? That’s the trouble with ye, Winslow.
column153: Y’know how y’eat grass without haven’ yer teeth?
column154: Ye rip it out and ye swallow it.
column168: You’re drunk, you don’t know what yer talkin’--
column171: Yer fond of me lobster, ain’t ye?
column175: Let Neptune strike ye dead, Winslow!
column176: Hark, Triton, Hark! Bellow, and bid our father, the sea king, rise up from the depths, full- foul in his fury, black waves teeming with salt-foam, to smother this young mouth with pungent slime...  ... to choke ye, engorging yer organs till ye turn blue and bloated with bilge and brine and can scream no more... only when, he, crowned in cockle shells with slithering tentacled tail and steaming beard, takes up his fell, be-finnèd arm -– his coral-tined trident screeches banshee-like in the tempest and runs you through the gullet, bursting ye, a bulging bladder no more, but a blasted bloody film now -- a nothing for the Harpies and the souls of dead sailors to peck and claw and feed upon, only to be lapped up and swallowed by the infinite waters of the dread emperor himself, forgotten to any man, to any time, forgotten to any god or devil, forgotten even to the sea... for any stuff or part of Winslow, even any scantling of your soul, is Winslow no more, but is now itself the sea.
column177: Queer way to wear yer shoes.
column178: Mm-hm. The sun is over the yardarm. Best find me some winks afore the day draws farther on.
column179: Get to yer duties or I’ll give you a real keelhauling.
column182: She swung her hips, she winked her eyes, that sassy little whore, So I took her in, I gave her gin, and danced her on the floor!
column183: Oh 'round and 'round the sofa, boys, wasn't it a show She grabbed hold of my bobstay and she wouldn't let it go!
column185: Oh, where have all the evenings gone? Oh, where is the ale and whisky I’ve tasted? Gone the same way as the pay I done wasted, On a Monday morning. If but the birds were gin, If but the sun was a hearty reveler, If I might give someone else me liver, On a Monday morning.
column186: My lover she lies asleep, My lover is warm, and her heart is mellow,
column197: Don’t be spilling any of yer beans to me.
column198: Never did like being confided to.
column199: Yer guilty conscience is ever as tiresome-borin’ as any a guilty conscience.
column202: Shut up yer own rag box.
column208: Certain, says I! I’ll report ye, I’ll bring the inspector up--
column209: Who’s reportin’ who? Ephraim Winslow? Or Thomas Howard?
column212: Jesus, Mary and Joseph, Tommy. Last night you made a confession ‘twould make a saint swear. I don’t have nothin’ to confess, but you, Tommy, a-spillin’ yer beans... now look what it’s done to ye. It’s made ye mad. I knew ye was mad when y’smashed up the life boat just now, a-chasing me with an axe, tryin’ to kill ‘Ol Tom. Don’t y’trust me, Tommy?
column213: Better hand me the dinner knife you pocketed. Y’aint safe with it.
column217: Look at yer shiverin’. Yer so mad, y’know not up from down. How long have we been on this rock? Five week? Two days? Where are we? Help me to recollect, who are you again, Tommy?
column218: I’m probably a fig’ment of your ‘magination. This rock is a fig’ment of yer ‘magination, too. Yer probably wand’rin’ through a grove of tag alders, up in north Canady, like a frostbitten maniac a- talkin’ to yerself, knee-deep in the snow, the blizzard overtakin’ ye.
column222: Be my guest. You’ll get drowned.
column224: Fiery pit! Ain’t there no justice left in this world?
column229: It started as a sliver of a cut is all...
column230: ... from the forestaysail when we shoved off...
column233: ... his chops was locked tighter than an anchor bend--
column234: What were it yer accused me of? Y’already told me y’had me figgerd--
column237: Y’have a way with words, Tommy.
column241: Look at ye, handsome lad, with eyes bright as a lady. Come to this rock playin’ the tough, ye make me laugh with yer false grum. Ye pretended to some mystery in yer quietudes, but there ain’t no mystery, yer an open book. A picture, says I. A painted actress screaming in the footlights, a bitch what wants to be coveted for nothin’ but being born, cryin’ bout the silver spoon what should’ve been yers. Now look at ye cryin’.
column242: Boo! Boo! What’re y’to do? Look at ye. Look at ye. Will y’kill me? Will ye? Will y’kill me like y’done that gull?
column243: Would ye best me then? If y’break,
column248: Y’wish to see what’s in that lantern?
column249: Y’said yer a God fearin’ man, Tommy?  Them’s truth, Tommy!
column250: and cast them down to Davy Jones. And others, still blind, yet in it see all divine graces and to Fiddler’s Green sent, where no man is suffered to want and toil, but is
